thread.title: Here’s what an emerging-markets mess could do to U.S. stocks
thread.title_full: Here’s what an emerging-markets mess could do to U.S. stocks - MarketWatch

author: Shawn Langlois
title: Here’s what an emerging-markets mess could do to U.S. stocks
text:
Life after the latest Fed meeting begins today. And, well, it feels a lot like life before — a nagging uncertainty, smothered in worry, with a side of Wall Street hand-holding.
“Now we will go back to the fretting about the Fed’s timing and the interim data, which will be sliced and diced,” said Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment officer at Charles Schwab SCHW, -3.43% in a note titled, “When Doves Cry.” Yes. More of the same.
She isn’t alone in voicing her view that the calming of global tensions and some wage improvements will likely bring on a hike by year end, though fewer and fewer seem to believe it. Sonders pointed out that the odds traders assign to an increase in October dropped from 44% to 32% and from 64% to 56% in December, according to Bloomberg data.
So the Fed guessing game will continue to dominate financial banter in the coming months, leaving investors to flap in the wind with more turbulent days ahead. Here’s why you should tune out.
The decision “isn’t necessarily positive news, because we are still left with the uncertainty that has been plaguing the market for some time,” said Franklin Templeton’s Mark Mobius . “We know that the markets dislike uncertainty, so we could also be left with continued volatility through year-end.”
If that doesn’t quite satisfy today’s bearish hunger, take a look at our chart of the day (see below) and find out why one fairly reliable indicator is pointing to some pretty lean times. Our call isn’t exactly brimming with confidence for the rest of the year, either.
Key market gauges It’s uglying up fast as Fed-fueled global growth worries are taking hold. Futures on the Dow YMU5, -1.52% and the S&P ESU5, -1.91% are seeing losses of 1% heading into the opening bell. In Asia ADOW, +0.21% there was mostly green, outside of the Nikkei NIK, -1.96% which fell 2% as the dollar USDJPY, -0.40% got creamed by the yen . Still, the Shanghai Composite SHCOMP, +0.38% managed just a 0.4% gain. Europe SXXP, -2.29% is slumping, as banks take a beating. Gold GCU5, +1.85% is, understandably, up nearly 2%, and crude oil CLV5, -3.56% is inching south.
The Quote: Bloomberg “I think most of us would have followed him into the gates of hell carrying suntan oil after that.” — Dolly Singh, former head of talent acquisition at SpaceX, describing what it was like to work with Elon Musk after the team suffered a failed rocket launch.
The stat AFP/Getty Images This Lincoln House in Mumbai. $120 million — that’s how much one Indian billionaire paid for the pad above, a former U.S. consulate in Mumbai. He plans on using it for his occasional weekend home, Bloomberg reported .
The economy Obviously, the big event came and went, so there are just some economic scraps to pick through today. At 10:00 a.m. Eastern, we get August leading indicators, followed two hours later by second-quarter flow-of-funds numbers.
